Head Quarters Dist of Tennessee Nashville Tenn Oct. 29th /64 General Orders) No 73 ) ) Before a Military Commission [missing] [missing] at Gallatin Tennessee pursuant to Special orders No 160. Head Quarters Dist of Tennessee – dated July 9th 1864. And of which Lieut Col. MClain F. Wood 10th Ill. Vet. Volunteers was President – was arraigned and tried. Alfred Fowler of Sumner Co. Tenn. Charge: “Being a Bushwhacker Specification: “In this that the said Alfred Fowler of Sumner Co. Tennessee did sometime in the month of June 1864 or thereabouts join a band of Bushwhackers which is known as “Lay & Harper’s Gang” and that he the said Alfred Fowler – since his connection with said band of Bushwhackers has been skulking through the County of Sumner in the state of Tennessee and adjoining Counties with said band of Bushwhackers whose business it [missing [missing] and now is to Shoot at Soldiers belonging to the Army of the United States, and to Plunder, rob, and damage, unarmed Citizens friendly to the United States” Charge 2nd : “Horse Stealing” Specification: “In this that the said Alfred Fowler of Sumner County Tennessee did at different times and places in the County of
Page 2 of 2
Sumner Tenn. And adjoining Counties since his connection with “Lay and Harper’s” band of Bushwhackers, together with said Marauders, take and steal Horses – the personal property of Citizens of said Counties To which Charges and Specifications the accused pleaded Guilty Findings: Of the specifications first charge “Guilty” Of the first charge “Guilty” Of the Specifications second charge “Guilty” Of the second charge “Guilty” Sentence: And the commission does therefore sentence him Alfred Fowler of Sumner County Tenn. to be confined for the term of three years at hard labor in the Penitentiary at Nashville Tenn. or in such other place as may be designated by the proper authority” The proceedings and findings and Sentence in the case of Alfred Fowler of Sumner Co. Tenn. is approved and confirmed. The Provost Marshal of Nashville Tenn. will see the sentence is properly carried into effect. By Command of Maj Gen Rousseau Official (Signed) Thos. C. Williams Signed B. H. Polk A.A.A.G. Assistant Adjutant General. A True Copy E. L. Anderson Capt. Hunter Brooks Post Prv Mar Nashville Tenn Capt and Asst Pro Marshal
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: General order No. 73 from Major General Rousseau sentencing Alfred Fowler of Sumner County to three years hard labor in the penitentiary in Nashville for the crime of "being a bushwhacker" with the Lay & Harper Gang, shooting at Federal Soldiers, plundering, robbing, horse stealing, and damaging unarmed citizens friendly to the United States.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: General orders are published directives issued by a commander, binding upon all personnel under his command to affect policies or procedures unique to a unit's situation not addressed by service regulations. General orders have the force of law within the unit they are issued. This Order is the result of a military tribunal trying an individual for unlawful guerilla warfare, which was relatively widespread in the occupied south and west of the Mississippi.
